nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
General site characteristics
nodes.body: KolokKo logs is located in an eponymous locale on the left side of the Senge TsangpoSengge gtsang po valley. The site occupies a sandy flat in the valley bottom. On a formation at the edge of the valley is Kolog KharKo logs mkhar (A-125), the ruins of an archaic stronghold. KolokKo logs consists of five double-course enclosures, which are not aligned in the cardinal directions. These enclosures were primarily built of unhewn light-colored pieces of granite of variable length. The enclosures are all very fragmentary, which is probably linked to the construction of an old pastoral camp at the site (it appears to contain stones extracted from the funerary structures). The site is now endangered again by the reestablishment of a pastoral camp by two families, which recently emigrated here from GyamukRgya smug.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS2
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS2 (6.4 m x 11 m) now consists of just two neatly-built double-course wall segments (50 cm hick) (38.357΄ / 32.076΄). The upright stones in these walls project 10 cm to 30 cm above the ground surface.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS3
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS3 (7.8 m x 6.8 m) has parts of all four walls intact (38.364΄ / 32.060΄). This enclosure was divided into two cells. Its double-course upright stone walls are of the same design as FS2.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS4
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS4 (4 m across) had been reduced to tiny fragments of upright stone walls of the type found in FS2 and FS3 (38.375΄ / 32.007΄).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS5
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS5 consists of a dispersion of double-course wall fragments that stretch over a transection of 21 m (38.401΄ / 32.071΄). Several discrete enclosures may have comprised FS5. The walls are composed of parallel courses of stones that project prominently above ground level (up to a height of 30 cm).
